Award.AwardTitle: PECASE: A Quality Framework for Interpretive Engineering Education Research

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research initiation grant seeks to combine elements of the total quality management (TQM) movement from engineering with a framework for evaluating qualitative research that will be developed during the project. There is a need to be able to judge the results of qualitative research; this project will help achieve this goal. Additionally having a clearly delineated framework that draws from language familiar to engineers may help make qualitative research results easier to translate between research communities.

The broader significance and importance of this project lie primarily in building networks and capacity for research as well as being able to more broadly communicate research results. The proposed framework, if widely accepted, may serve in the education of graduate students. Additionally improving qualitative research techniques will help in studies of equity issues with under-represented groups in engineering. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers by making investments that lead to emerging new fields of engineering, or shifting existing fields. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by supporting the development of innovative learning systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a rapidly changing and increasingly complex world, engineering programs are being transformed to prepare students for the engineering workplace of the 21st century. These transformations are informed by the empirical knowledge and evidence created through systematic engineering education research. Engineering education researchers are increasingly employing qualitative research methods to investigate the intricacies and complexities that are at play when students develop into professional engineers.

The project "PECASE: A Quality Framework for Interpretive Engineering Education Research" supports researchers who employ qualitative methods by developing and disseminating a coherent way to conceptualize, plan for, and articulate the quality and trustworthiness of their findings. The Quality Framework was developed in a participatory process that engaged engineering education researchers across the nation. Through this process the Quality Framework is firmly grounded in the needs of the community and a consistent commitment to usability and impact. As a consequence the Quality Framework can serve researchers as a tool in planning and conducting research and as a shared conceptual language to articulate and discuss issues or features of quality in their work.

The Quality Framework was validated across a range of engineering education studies and was also found to be highly effective as a teaching tool to introduce novices, such as graduate students, to qualitative engineering education research. Consequently, the products disseminated as part of this grant are increasingly being adopted as key resources in the community and help researchers to improve the quality of their qualitative studies and increase the impact of their work through embedding and demonstrating its quality.
